awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A Dedicated Foundry Service for Emerging Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of advancements in the use of emerging materials for semiconductor manufacturing. The dedicated emerging materials foundry could alleviate the chip shortage concerns which have disproportionately affected small and medium-sized businesses which use chips in their products. There may be four classes of customers: scientists/engineers in the fields of chemistry, biology, etc.; scientists/engineers who grow nanomaterial in their labs; small/medium sized internet of things companies; and semiconductor packaging facilities that are interested in integrating chips with their existing products. For each class, an application-specific chip will be developed which will harness certain unique properties of 2-dimensional materials. The low-to-medium volume production line of the proposed business will enable the flexibility to meet the targeted needs of a large variety of customers who will not be reliant on the rigid tape-out schedules of foundries.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a dedicated emerging materials foundry for producing novel chip designs using unconventional materials with a quick turnaround time. With the continued scaling of transistors in silicon chips, Moore’s law has reached a phase of stagnation. To overcome this challenge, novel semiconductor materials have been used to experimentally demonstrate superior performance in ultra-scaled transistors. Despite their fascinating properties, there has been very little progress in transitioning these state-of-the-art technologies from the lab to the marketplace. As a result, there are hardly any foundries today which manufacture chips based on novel and emerging semiconductors. All this while, the growth of 2-dimensional materials on a large scale, which is crucial in mass producing transistors, has been drastically improved. This is a unique opportunity to commercialize an emerging materials semiconductor foundry at a time when the US wants to regain its leadership in semiconductor and chip manufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In the course of an insightful investigation funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) through the I-Corps program, aimed at establishing a dedicated foundry service for emerging 2D materials, we engaged in a comprehensive series of interviews with a diverse range of stakeholders. This included companies and academic experts, along with personnel from national laboratories, all of whom play a pivotal role in the materials science ecosystem. One of the most salient findings from these dialogues was the pronounced demand for advanced 2D materials across a variety of sectors. These materials are celebrated for their extraordinary properties, such as high strength, exceptional thermal and electrical conductivity, and unique optical characteristics, which stand to transform a multitude of industries. By enhancing product performance and introducing novel capabilities, the application of 2D materials like graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs), and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN), among others, could lead to breakthroughs in electronics, energy storage, and even biotechnology.

Another critical need that emerged from our interactions was the development of chemisensors specifically tailored for the food industry. Stakeholders highlighted the urgent requirement for innovative solutions capable of detecting spoilage, adulteration, and ensuring food safety. These sensors, leveraging the unique capabilities of 2D materials such as graphene, could provide real-time, accurate analysis, significantly impacting public health and industry standards. The insights gained through this NSF-funded initiative underscore the importance of advancing material science and sensor technology to meet contemporary challenges, paving the way for significant industrial and societal benefits.


Last Modified: 04/01/2024
Modified by: Saptarshi Das
